repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

comment_data.body: Might be a good idea to make `num_holder` be used inside the genexp, as well as being in the iteration expression. That way there isn't an opportunity for future optimisations to optimise out what we're testing by not including it in the scope struct. Similarly perhap pass `tuple` in as a parameter from the python code, so this can't be converted to a list comp.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -376,3 +376,34 @@ def test_non_built_in_reversed_function(py_v):
         vint.push_back(e)
     for e in reversed(vint):
         print(e)
+
+
+# Not strictly a C++ iterator test, but an issue with generator
+# expressions and iteration from c++ const attributes so in this
+# file as a related issue.  Mainly a test that it compiles.
+# GH-5558
+cdef extern from *:
+    """
+    struct ConstNumberHolder {
+        const int num;
+
+        explicit ConstNumberHolder(int num) :
+            num(num)
+        {}
+    };
+    """
+    cppclass ConstNumberHolder:
+        ConstNumberHolder(int num)
+
+        const int num
+
+def test_iteration_from_const_member(int num):
+    """
+    >>> test_iteration_from_const_member(5)
+    (0, 1, 2, 3, 4)
+    """
+    num_holder = new ConstNumberHolder(num)
+    try:
+        return tuple(i for i in range(num_holder.num))

comment_data.body:
For your first suggestion: `num_holder` itself isn't included in the scope structure. It just took the `const int` type from `num_holder.num` and used that in the scope struct.

The second suggestion is a good one. It's a valid concern that the whole " `tuple` from generator expression" could be optimize out the generator expression. I'll modify it sightly I think and just return the generator expression and evaluate that in the interpreted doctest
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -376,3 +376,34 @@ def test_non_built_in_reversed_function(py_v):
         vint.push_back(e)
     for e in reversed(vint):
         print(e)
+
+
+# Not strictly a C++ iterator test, but an issue with generator
+# expressions and iteration from c++ const attributes so in this
+# file as a related issue.  Mainly a test that it compiles.
+# GH-5558
+cdef extern from *:
+    """
+    struct ConstNumberHolder {
+        const int num;
+
+        explicit ConstNumberHolder(int num) :
+            num(num)
+        {}
+    };
+    """
+    cppclass ConstNumberHolder:
+        ConstNumberHolder(int num)
+
+        const int num
+
+def test_iteration_from_const_member(int num):
+    """
+    >>> test_iteration_from_const_member(5)
+    (0, 1, 2, 3, 4)
+    """
+    num_holder = new ConstNumberHolder(num)
+    try:
+        return tuple(i for i in range(num_holder.num))

comment_data.body:
I think reversing this condition makes it easier to read.
```suggestion
                while type.is_cv_qualified or (type.is_reference and not type.is_fake_reference):
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1720,14 +1720,20 @@ def _handle_ExprNode(self, node, do_visit_children):
                 cname = EncodedString(Naming.genexpr_arg_prefix + Symtab.punycodify_name(str(name_source)))
                 name_decl = Nodes.CNameDeclaratorNode(pos=pos, name=name)
                 type = node.type
-                if type.is_reference and not type.is_fake_reference:
-                    # It isn't obvious whether the right thing to do would be to capture by reference or by
-                    # value (C++ itself doesn't know either for lambda functions and forces a choice).
-                    # However, capture by reference involves converting to FakeReference which would require
-                    # re-analysing AttributeNodes. Therefore I've picked capture-by-value out of convenience
-                    # TODO - could probably be optimized by making the arg a reference but the closure not
-                    # (see https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/2468)
-                    type = type.ref_base_type
+                while ((type.is_reference and not type.is_fake_reference) or
+                        type.is_cv_qualified):

comment_data.body:
BTW, this looks so generic (unpack the plain type) that it could be a helper function. From a quick look, there are a few places where we unpack both `const` and reference types.

Since this is the first time we use a loop for this, though, can there be more than two levels? What we previously did was to first unpack references and then const/volatile. Can there be more? Meaning, is this really worth a loop? I certainly don't think there is a reasons to do it differently in different places.

(I'd prefer to keep the long comment here, though.)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1720,14 +1720,20 @@ def _handle_ExprNode(self, node, do_visit_children):
                 cname = EncodedString(Naming.genexpr_arg_prefix + Symtab.punycodify_name(str(name_source)))
                 name_decl = Nodes.CNameDeclaratorNode(pos=pos, name=name)
                 type = node.type
-                if type.is_reference and not type.is_fake_reference:
-                    # It isn't obvious whether the right thing to do would be to capture by reference or by
-                    # value (C++ itself doesn't know either for lambda functions and forces a choice).
-                    # However, capture by reference involves converting to FakeReference which would require
-                    # re-analysing AttributeNodes. Therefore I've picked capture-by-value out of convenience
-                    # TODO - could probably be optimized by making the arg a reference but the closure not
-                    # (see https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/2468)
-                    type = type.ref_base_type
+                while ((type.is_reference and not type.is_fake_reference) or
+                        type.is_cv_qualified):

comment_data.body:
I've factored it out into a helper function.

I've kept the loop because I'm a bit paranoid about the order of ref/const/volatile and if that matters. I suspect it's unnecessary, but not completely sure.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1720,14 +1720,20 @@ def _handle_ExprNode(self, node, do_visit_children):
                 cname = EncodedString(Naming.genexpr_arg_prefix + Symtab.punycodify_name(str(name_source)))
                 name_decl = Nodes.CNameDeclaratorNode(pos=pos, name=name)
                 type = node.type
-                if type.is_reference and not type.is_fake_reference:
-                    # It isn't obvious whether the right thing to do would be to capture by reference or by
-                    # value (C++ itself doesn't know either for lambda functions and forces a choice).
-                    # However, capture by reference involves converting to FakeReference which would require
-                    # re-analysing AttributeNodes. Therefore I've picked capture-by-value out of convenience
-                    # TODO - could probably be optimized by making the arg a reference but the closure not
-                    # (see https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/2468)
-                    type = type.ref_base_type
+                while ((type.is_reference and not type.is_fake_reference) or
+                        type.is_cv_qualified):

commit.message:
Avoid creating const members in closure structs

Fixes #5558 and hopefully #5333

Make test return generator expression

Stops any optimizations destroying the validity of the test
Factor remove_cv_ref into a utility code function

title: Avoid creating const members in closure structs
